MS written by Georg Luehmann and signed by M. Botanic Garden

Referring to my letters of 11th and 23rd December last, in which I had the honor to point out the impossibility of carrying on the service of the Department with the utterly inadequate means available for the item of Stores &c, I have now the honor to solicit, that you will be pleased to grant the transfer of the sum of £120.- voted for a test plantation in the ranges, to the item for Stores. Since there are no funds available for fencing in any ground, for the erection of a superintendent's dwelling and other expenditure, necessarily connected with the inauguration of such a plantation, I beg respectfully to submit that this work may stand over till the new financial year, so that by the transfer of this sum I may be enabled to meet the unavoidable expenditure for forage for the carthorse, tools, coal for the hot houses, timber nails paint and oil for small repairs, paper &c for the museum and many other necessary articles too numerous too particularize.
If my request should be favorably considered I will at once forward requisitions specifying the articles most urgently needed.
I have the honor to be
You will be aware that half the original vote for Stores &c was withdrawn from the Botanic Garden, in consequence of which I am left without means for the second half of the financial year.

The Honorable the Commissioner of Lands & Survey.
M's letter was referred to the Secretary of Agriculture, A. Wallis, who acknowledged it on 11 January 1873.
